items.title: RBA governor's four reasons for rate hike as major banks react to increase

items.title: RBA pulls the trigger on rates; gold and silver rebound
items.summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia has increased interest rates for the first time since November 2023, hiking the official cash rate to 3.85%. It says it now expects inflation to remain well above its 2-3% target for longer, leaving the door open for further rate increases. For more on this, Stephanie Youssef spoke with HSBC chief economist Paul Bloxham. Despite the decision, the Australian share market finished the session strong, amid a strong global stocks rebound that included a gold and silver price recovery. For more, Stephanie Youssef spoke with Mark Gardner, CEO at MPC Markets.

items.title: The key to a long life? One factor may matter more than we thought

items.title: Interest rate rise ends two-year pause
items.summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia has ended a two-year hiatus by raising interest rates to 15 per cent, sparking a fierce political debate over whether government spending or private demand is fuelling persistent inflation. While the Treasurer defends the budget and points to external pressures, the Opposition and the Greens argue that current policy settings are punishing everyday Australians and ignoring alternative economic levers.

items.title: Police search for Dezi Freeman: 'the largest manhunt we have seen in Victoria'
items.summary: A fresh search in Victoria's High Country has begun for accused police killer Dezi Freeman, with detectives now believing the 56-year-old is most likely dead. Mr Freeman is accused of killing two police officers and severely injuring a third after they executed a search warrant on a rural property near the Victorian town of Porepunkah last year. Police are now focusing on a new search area in the vast Mount Buffalo National Park.

items.title: Royals, power and public trust: the Epstein files continue to rock the Establishment
items.summary: From London to Oslo, institutions built on tradition and public trust are being tested by demands for transparency, accountability and justice. In Britain, both a former prince and a senior political figure are being urged to answer questions about their past associations with Jeffrey Epstein. While in Norway, a criminal trial involving the Crown Princess’s son is unfolding under intense public scrutiny.

items.title: Australia confirms closure of Afghan embassy amid Taliban pressure
items.summary: The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has confirmed plans to close the Afghan Embassy in Australia, leaving many members of Australia's Afghan community on edge. Experts say the decision follows a demand from the Taliban that all embassies under the control of an anti-Taliban ambassador be closed. While some members of the Afghan diaspora in Australia say they expect the closure to have little impact, for others, it's a deeply concerning development.

items.title: First cohort of migrants under Tuvalu deal arrive in Australia
items.summary: The Falepili Union treaty between Australia and Tuvalu was hailed as a global first-of-its kind, with one provision of the agreement allowing up to 280 Tuvaluans to relocate to Australia each year as rising seas threaten their homeland. The first cohort of migrants under the deal are now arriving in Australia. But with just a small Tuvaluan diaspora here, they're facing a challenge to settle in to their new home, while maintaining a connection to community and culture.

items.title: Grave concerns after one month of anti-government unrest in Iran
items.summary: It's been a month since one of Iran's deadliest periods of anti-government unrest in the history of the Islamic Republic. While mass protests have subsided amid a crackdown by security forces, a US-based human rights group has confirmed the deaths of more than 6,000 people, warning the total could stand at more than 20,000. Iran's official death toll is just over 3,000. There are also grave concerns for the tens of thousands who have been arrested.

items.title: From cat videos to conspiracies — is older people's phone use a problem?
items.summary: Some parents' and grandparents' screen time has become a concern. But what do we know about phone use and the ageing brain?

items.title: New citizens welcomed to Australia as thousands turn out for rallies across the country
items.summary: Around 18,000 people became Australians on Monday, as thousands joined Invasion Day rallies and hundreds attended anti-immigration protests.

items.title: Australians reflect on the nation's history on Australia Day 2026
items.summary: Australia Day has been marked across the country with citizenship ceremonies and Australian of the Year awards. The day has also been marked by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people who have gathered across the country for annual events marking January 26 - including Invasion Day rallies.

items.title: How this city became a flashpoint in Trump's immigration crackdown
items.summary: An escalation in immigration enforcement and fatal shootings have put a spotlight on Minneapolis.

items.title: Gold breaks $7k in fresh record as silver surges, with further gains tipped
items.summary: The milestones come as geopolitical tensions and market jitters mount.

items.title: Rallies around Australia amid debate over date of Australia Day | SBS News In Easy English 26 January 2026
items.summary: A daily 5-minute news bulletin for English learners and people with a disability.

items.title: 'Lived to help': Grief and outrage in Minneapolis after ICE kills ICU nurse Alex Pretti
items.summary: United States Federal Agents have shot and killed another person in Minneapolis, just three weeks after the killing of Renee Good. With growing demands the government withdraw ICE agents from the city, President Donald Trump has signalled their possible intention to leave.

items.title: Emergencies declared, flights grounded, millions lose power as deep freeze hits US
items.summary: A massive winter storm has swept across large parts of the United States, bringing heavy snow, ice and dangerously cold temperatures to states from Texas to New England. The storm has so far caused more than a million people to lose power, and thousands of flights have been grounded. Nearly 20 states have now declared weather emergencies, as the National Weather Service warns of continued hazardous conditions in coming days.

items.title: 'I have two homes': Five migrants share what being Australian means to them
items.summary: Hailing from all around the world, these five migrants share why they're grateful to be Australian, despite social cohesion challenges.

items.title: Astronaut Katherine Bennell-Pegg named Australian of the Year
items.summary: The 2026 Australian of the Year winners have been announced at the National Arboretum in Canberra. Thirty-three finalists from astronauts to doctors have been recognised for their contributions to Australian society.

items.title: The Aussie dollar has reached a 15-month high. What does this mean for us?
items.summary: A strong Australian dollar could be welcome news for overseas travellers and household budgets.

items.title: Man charged over 'abhorrent' threat to Sydney mosque
items.summary: The material posted to Sydney's Lakemba Mosque singled out Muslims, Middle Eastern communities, Indigenous people and left-wing politicians.

items.title: A Royal Commission has been called. Now what?
items.summary: .After weeks of political pressure, the Prime Minister this month announced a Royal Commission into the rise in antisemitism and factors behind the second-deadliest mass shooting in Australian history. It is the latest of a series of Royal Commissions into wide-ranging issues, but what is a Royal Commission and what does it do?

items.title: A century ago, the average Australian was a 24-year-old man. Who is it now?
items.summary: Australia celebrates its national day on Monday, but do we really know who we are?

items.title: 'They think we're billionaires': This couple inherited a manor. It's been anything but idyllic
items.summary: Inheriting property is often complex. When Anne-Sophie and Olivier inherited a 500-year-old château, it presented some unique challenges.

items.title: Fighting fakes and food fraud, this team knows where your festive dish really comes from
items.summary: Almost five million people in Australia fall ill each year from unsafe or contaminated food. Australian technology is helping combat this growing global problem.

items.title: Do you know where your food is really from? This Australian scientist does
items.summary: Millions of people globally fall ill each year, from unsafe or contaminated foods. Some is due to food fraud, the act of purposely selling fake, mis-labelled or substituted food products for financial gain. Australian scientists have developed new ways to combat this multi-billion dollar problem.

items.title: Rights for women deteriorating four years after Taliban takeover in Afghanistan
items.summary: It’s been more than four years since the Taliban took control of Afghanistan - and according to human rights organisations, the situation for women and girls is only getting progressively worse - with a near-total exclusion from most public employment and education. The United Nations has warned the country is expected to remain one of the world’s largest humanitarian crises for the year ahead.

items.title: 50 years since Concorde's first commercial flight, memories linger on
items.summary: The world’s first supersonic passenger plane, Concorde, made its maiden commercial flight 50 years ago this month on 21 January 1976. Its delta-wing design and drooping nose made it instantly recognisable, and although it went out of service in 2003, it is still remembered to this day.

items.title: Allowed to beg, forbidden to study: Why conditions for Afghan women are worsening
items.summary: Despite an injection of more than $260 million in Australian aid, the situation for women in Afghanistan remains 'bleak'.

items.title: Is the A$ headed for 70USc?
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Tony Sycamore from IG Markets about the day's sharemarket action as the Australian dollar and gold price charge towards new milestones.

items.title: What next - if anything - for the Coalition?
items.summary: The Coalition’s unity has reached a new low following what's being described as a 'terminal' breakdown between key frontbenchers, marking their third significant split since the 2025 election. While leadership maintains that the door remains open for future cooperation, analysts suggest the in-fighting is further alienating a public that is increasingly turning toward minor parties and independent alternatives.

items.title: Australia’s summers being transformed as climate change drives heatwaves
items.summary: Australian summers are undergoing what scientists call a "total transformation," with a new study from World Weather Attribution revealing the country can now expect heatwaves every five years on average. The study's researchers say climate change made Australia's blistering heatwave in early January five times more likely, and there's an urgent need for the country to adapt to changed conditions. The warning comes as the country's south-eastern states prepare for what's forecast to be a prolonged, severe heatwave starting this weekend.

items.title: President Trump keeps world leaders on their toes
items.summary: .US President Donald Trump has used the World Economic Forum in Davos to push a new security framework for the Arctic, and signal what he says is momentum towards ending the war in Ukraine. The week has also exposed deep divisions among allies over Greenland and Europe’s role in global security.

items.title: Ley confident in leadership as Albanese says she was 'undermined from day one'
items.summary: The prime minister said he had "given up worrying about what happens" within the Coalition.

items.title: US officially withdraws from the World Health Organization
items.summary: Global health experts said the withdrawal poses risks for the US, the WHO and the world.

items.title: Australian summer is undergoing a 'total transformation', scientists warn
items.summary: Scientists say climate change made this summer's blistering heatwave five times more likely and cities need to adapt urgently.

items.title: 'Left out and ostracised': The social media ban's uneven execution — and other effects
items.summary: It's been six weeks since Australians under 16 were banned from most social media platforms. What impact has the ban had?

items.title: 'Profoundly sorry': Albanese apologises to Bondi attack victims' loved ones
items.summary: The prime minister has spoken at the national day of mourning memorial at the Sydney Opera House.

items.title: Surprise jobs report boosts chance of February rate rise
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Johnathan McMenamin from Barrenjoey and Adam Dawes from Shaw and Parnters as Australia's unemployment rate falls from 4.3% to 4.1% in December increasing the chance of an interest rate rise in a fortnight.

items.title: Trump’s Greenland U-turn, Syria clashes force Kurds into retreat & China ‘brings home the bacon’
items.summary: Is Donald Trump’s retreat from tariffs and military threats over Greenland - a NATO reset or a tactical pause? Syria edges toward reunification but at a major cost to the Kurds – and IS group fighters escape. Plus how a farm girl’s plea from rural China went hog-wild online.

items.title: Jim Chalmers: 'The Coalition is a smoking ruin'
items.summary: The Coalition has reached a breaking point as the National Party officially splits from the Liberals, following a mass frontbench walkout over controversial hate speech legislation. While Opposition Leader Sussan Ley attempted to block some of the resignations to maintain unity, former colleagues and political rivals alike are labeling the fallout a "smoking ruin" that threatens the future of the alternative government.

items.title: 'Existential moment': After a second split, is it game over for the Coalition?
items.summary: Experts say the new anti-hate laws may not be the only reason behind the recent Coalition split, with Nationals being "really worried" about losing voters.

items.title: President Trump says his Board of Peace is 'the greatest board ever formed'
items.summary: Saudi Arabia, Turkiye, Egypt, Jordan, Indonesia, Pakistan and Qatar have accepted US President Donald Trump's invitation to join the so-called 'Board of Peace.' Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has also publicly confirmed Israel's participation, while Vladimir Putin says he's considering Trump's invitation to join. Amid concerns the board of peace will pose a threat to the United Nations, the UN Secretary General has urged continued commitment to international law.

items.title: Kenedi made almost $300k as a surrogate overseas. Should Australians also be paid?
items.summary: Some experts believe Australian surrogacy laws are ineffective and lead many couples desperate to start a family to seek options overseas.

items.title: 'We sit by ourselves': Littleproud confirms Coalition split after mass Nationals resignation
items.summary: Eight Nationals frontbenchers have quit the shadow cabinet in protest following the resignation of three of their colleagues.

items.title: Global markets slide on Trump's Europe tariff concerns
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Scott Phillips from The Motley Fool about the day's market action including why investors are concerned about Trump's latest threats, gold's new record and why BHP is edging closer to becoming Australia's largest listed company.

items.summary: Koala numbers in some areas are "concerning" researchers, who predict populations could become unsustainable.

items.title: The new United Nations? What to know about Donald Trump's 'Board of Peace'
items.summary: United States President Donald Trump has invited world leaders to join his so-called 'Board of Peace'. Conceived with a mandate to oversee the administration and reconstruction of Gaza, the plan has quickly ballooned in its planned remit.

items.title: What is the Chagos Islands deal, and why has Trump accused the UK of 'stupidity'?
items.summary: The UK agreed to hand the Chagos Islands to Mauritius in a deal that the Trump administration previously backed.

items.title: Macron warns of 'world without rules' after Trump shares texts from European leaders
items.summary: Emmanuel Macron said France preferred "respect to bullies" and rejected "unacceptable" tariffs.

items.summary: Experts say Trump's new body is susceptible to nepotism and corruption, and could undermine the role of the United Nations.

items.title: A fourth shark attack prompts more beach closures
items.summary: Following a period of heavy rain, a spate of suspected Bull shark attacks in New South Wales has left beach goers on edge. On Tuesday, a man was attacked by shark at Point Plomer beach near Port Macquarie on the state's Mid North Coast, escaping with only minor injuries. This is the fourth shark attacks in New South Wales over just two days.

items.title: Gun control, anti-hate laws pass the Lower House
items.summary: New gun control and anti-hate laws have passed the lower house of parliament in response to the Bondi terror attack at a Jewish festival, which killed 15 people last month. They are expected to pass into law, but the process has been far from harmonious.

items.title: Tariff threats trigger market volatility & BHP's record copper and iron ore production
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Julie Lee from FTSE Russell about the day's market action including how the market is dealing with Donald Trump's latest tariff threats and why investors didn't like BHP's record copper and iron ore production report.

items.title: NSW protest restrictions extended with limits allowing 'Invasion Day' rallies to proceed
items.summary: Protesters will be able to rally as planned on 26 January after the NSW Police commissioner made exemptions to ongoing protest restrictions.

items.summary: Experts say murky waters are prime conditions for shark attacks.

items.title: Three shark attacks in two days - experts warn of dangerous conditions
items.summary: A man is in a critical condition after the third shark attack at a Sydney beach in less than 48 hours. It follows attacks on Monday and Sunday, in which an 11 -year-old boy's surfboard was bitten by a shark and a 12-year-old boy was critically injured and remains in hospital.

items.title: 'A true maestro': Tributes pour in after Italian designer Valentino dies aged 93
items.summary: Known for dressing style icons from Jackie Kennedy to Audrey Hepburn, Valentino Garavani is being remembered as a master of elegance.

items.summary: US-Europe relations have been deteriorating, threatening NATO and leaving Australia in an awkward position.

items.title: What we know about the 'Board of Peace' Donald Trump has asked Australia to join
items.summary: Australia is "respectfully considering" its invitation to the board, which has a wide-ranging remit.

items.title: What's inside the government's gun reform bill? And why elements are 'a recipe for disaster'
items.summary: While gun reforms may provide "a sense of comfort" for some, critics argue everyday Australians will bear the cost and scrutiny of the changes.

items.title: Australia considers invitation to join Trump's 'Board of Peace' as world leaders react cautiously
items.summary: Initially established to oversee the future governance and reconstruction of Gaza, a draft charter suggests it would then expand.

items.title: Why Albanese's new hate speech laws were always going to face an uphill battle
items.summary: Labor has dropped racial vilification offences from its hate speech proposals. It's not the first time such a bid has failed.

items.title: South Australian premier's push for Adelaide Festival to drop Abdel-Fattah revealed in letter
items.summary: A newly published letter shows how the South Australian premier argued for Randa Abdel-Fattah to be dropped from Adelaide Writers' Week.

items.title: Thinking of changing your career this year? Consider these five steps before you do
items.summary: Between a shrinking job market, redundancies, and the threat of AI, changing careers in 2026 is different from how it used to be.

items.title: From lifeline to 'existential crisis': The high human cost of Victoria's public housing overhaul
items.summary: In the middle of a housing and cost-of-living crisis, the Victorian government is in the process of demolishing all 44 of Melbourne's public housing towers. Despite significant pushback and a parliamentary inquiry calling for an immediate halt to works, the Victorian government is pushing ahead with the plans.

items.title: Australia's 'most liveable' city is now the cheapest to rent houses
items.summary: The housing crisis has seen people finding it increasingly hard to rent or buy a house in Australia's capital cities. But while most of the country has seen prices going up there's one place where prices have gone down - and that's Melbourne, where rental prices have gone down almost two percent year on year. SBS's Cameron Carr spoke to Dr Nicola Powell from Domain, to find out what's driving down prices.

items.title: Darren lengthened his legs to be taller. Now he walks with a limp
items.summary: More people than ever before are making themselves taller with surgery. But while this can improve lives, some are left with long-term problems.

items.title: Government splits hate speech and gun laws in bid to save Bondi reforms
items.summary: The Albanese government has amended its proposed response to the Bondi Beach shootings, splitting its wide-ranging hate speech and gun reform package in two in a bid to secure passage through Parliament. Facing resistance from both the Coalition and the Greens over the breadth and rushed nature of the laws, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has made changes in hopes of receiving support from both political groups to pass each set of reforms.

items.title: How much for a coffee? New drinks are pushing prices to $8 or more
items.summary: Classic coffee styles continue to dominate sales, but a new trend reflects a wider shift in tastes shaped by Australia's increasingly diverse population.

items.title: She's a 'crazy pigeon lady'. He wants to revive a dying sport. This bird is their obsession
items.summary: Your perception of pigeons is wrong, these Australians say. Their lives revolve around them — but their worlds couldn't be more different.

items.title: Donald Trump appoints Tony Blair, Marco Rubio and more to Gaza 'board of peace'
items.summary: The group will supervise the temporary governance of Gaza, under a US plan.
